info.game_comments:
2009 Tournament of Champions final game 1.
From Las Vegas.

(1, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Omaha Beach in France.) This date of the Normandy invasion had been set for one day earlier, but because of bad weather, the 6,000 ships & 13,000 support planes had to wait

(2, 1).clue: Rock & roll & dancing are forbidden in small puritanical town; rebellious Ren to the rescue

(3, 1).clue: Popular in the '50s the slim skirts named for this writing implement have become chic again

(4, 1).clue: Breathe Right strips alleviate this sleeping noise, but became huge when Jerry Rice used them on the field

(5, 1).clue: On the day of his birth, this Greek messenger god stole his brother's cattle

(6, 1).clue: Your employer sends you this, the most common income-reporting tax statement in the United States

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Omaha Beach in France.)  Hours before his troops stormed these shores, he told them, "You are about to embark on the great crusade towards which we have striven these many months"

(2, 2).clue: Crusading Houston radio host exposes Chicken Ranch
(2, 2).correct response: The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas

(3, 2).clue: retro-housewife.com calls a '70s-style tunic in a '60s print a "mippie", a blend of mod & this word

(4, 2).clue: The bronchodilator Albuterol helps relieve this condition, from the Greek for "panting"

(5, 2).clue: One myth says that some of these, a hybrid of man & horse, were descended from the mares of Mount Pelion

(6, 2).clue: Bingo square coordinate that sounds like a synonym for "not malignant"

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Omaha Beach in France.)  German bunkers above the beach were named for these containers; some could only be taken by soldiers crawling up & tossing in explosives

(2, 3).clue: "Prince of Humbug" creates freak show, signs Jenny Lind

(3, 3).clue: This couturiere's iconic collarless jacket of 1954 is still part of her line today

(4, 3).clue: Nexium fights acid reflux, which also goes by this name, though it has nothing to do with the organ

(5, 3).clue: Ovid coined the name of this Greek god of dreams as an allusion to the forms seen in dreams

(6, 3).clue: In a sequel title, it precedes "X-Men United"

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Omaha Beach in France.)  Within days, the Allies had in place artificial harbors of sunken caissons; one harbor was dubbed "Port" this, the first name of a certain prime minister who favored the plan

(2, 4).clue: Charlemagne's son leads a revolution against his dad

(3, 4).clue: Too bad you didn't buy a Birkin one of these in the '80s; now the waiting list can take years

(4, 4).clue: Atorvastatin is the generic name of this cholesterol drug from Pfizer

(5, 4).clue: This winged creature with an eagle's head & a lion's body pulled Zeus' chariot

(6, 4).clue: In 2002 the last of this model Camaro rolled off the assembly line--a bright rally red convertible

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Omaha Beach in France.)  In the early hours of D-Day here at Pointe-Du-Hoc, members of this elite U.S. Army force braved heavy enemy fire to scale the steep cliffs & take out cannons

(2, 5).clue: Slave tries to win freedom by helping his master earn the love of a courtesan; when in Rome…
(2, 5).correct response: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum

(3, 5).clue: On or off a yacht, this neckline whose name is French for "boat" has been stylish for decades

(4, 5).clue: This medicine is sold under the brand names Feverall & Tylenol

(5, 5).clue: In Greek myth, these wood nymphs lived in trees & died when the trees died

(6, 5).clue: Triple-engined McDonnell Douglas plane whose maiden flight was August 29, 1970

(1, 1).clue: Gertrude Stein, in a famous line, said this "is a" this "is a" this "is a" this

(2, 1).clue: In 1984 he dashed off with Olympic gold in the 100m; in 1988 he did it again; then there are his 7 other golds…

(4, 1).clue: Featuring a crust with shallow sides, a filling & no top crust, it isn't a tramp, it's this 4-letter pastry

(5, 1).clue: This type of bed is named for the small wheels that allow it to roll under for storage

(6, 1).clue: Ding-dong!  This river that runs through Bath is calling

(1, 2).clue: A 1981 book by her was published in English as "Adieux: A Farewell to Sartre"

(2, 2).clue: At a Big 10 meet in Michigan in 1935, this grandson of a slave broke 3 world records & tied a fourth, all in an hour

(4, 2).clue: Traditionally oblong, this cream-filled pastry is often topped with chocolate icing

(5, 2).clue: This bed that can be folded up into a closet is named for its American inventor

(6, 2).clue: "Are you going to" this British seaside town?  In medieval times it hosted a 45-day trading fair

(1, 3).clue: She gained fame as a playwright & later wrote memoirs like "Pentimento"

(2, 3).clue: In 2003 she returned to London to run her first-ever marathon--in shoes, we might add

(4, 3).clue: It's the chocolate-foam concoction lumbering past your eyes here

(5, 3).clue: To make the bed so the sheets stay tucked in, use the tight-fitting triangular fold called this place's corner

(6, 3).clue: It's the name of the second-largest city in England & also of the largest city in Alabama

(1, 4).clue: This Frenchwoman who went by 1 name liked 1-name titles, like "Mitsou" & "Cheri"

(2, 4).clue: The Pre Classic, an Oregon track & field meet, is named for this legendary runner & subject of 2 major movies

(3, 4).clue: The hard tissue of a plant(5)

(4, 4).clue: 2-word term for teeny iced & decorated cakes; the French also use it to describe small, fancy cookies

(5, 4).clue: The name of this type of down comforter comes from the French for "down"

(6, 4).clue: Her novel "Persuasion" satirizes Bath & its fashionable denizens

(1, 5).clue: Clip the "tag" off a German building & you've got this creator of forensic sleuth Tempe Brennan of "Devil Bones"

(2, 5).clue: Among his many nicknames were "The Finnish Running Marvel" & "The Phantom Finn"

(4, 5).clue: If you have the panache, you can use this type of French icing made of chocolate & cream, heated & stirred together

(5, 5).clue: As a verb, this name of the long cylindrical pillow seen on the bed means "to support"

(6, 5).clue: An important seaport, this Welsh capital was once the world's largest coal shipper

(0, 0).clue: You have to go back over a century to find him, the last president who never had a vice president
